templateAssets.content:
Articulation Agreement Overview

This agreement outlines lower-division course requirements specific to the major. Students are strongly encouraged to consult an academic advisor to ensure they meet all degree requirements for their intended baccalaureate program.


Helpful Resources:

  • CSUB Catalog
  • Transfer Admission Requirements
  • Academic Advising Student Centers
  • CSUB Program Pathways Mapper


Course Equivalency Information for 4-Year Institutions

Students and staff can explore course transfer equivalencies through the Transfer Evaluation System (TES). Equivalency agreements are updated regularly and subject to change. For the most current information, please refer to TES or contact the Articulation Office.

seriesAttributes.content: Course is articulated in more than one agreement but credit can only apply to one

attributes.content: Minimum grade required: C or better

templateAssets.content:
• Students who have taken Biology or Chemistry coursework should check the Articulation Agreement by the Department of the respective community colleges. The agreement may articulate differently, and it may determine whether the entire Biology and/or Chemistry sequence needs to be completed to receive appropriate course credit for the major requirements at CSUB.
  • A modification to the standard GE program has been approved, allowing the possibility of satisfying some GE requirements through the major. Please see the Chemistry and Biochemistry General Education Courses and Notes in the CSUB catalog for further information.

Chemistry is the central science that encompasses the study of matter in all its forms. This branch of science describes the fundamental structures, composition, and characteristics of atoms and molecules, which leads to an understanding of chemical reactivity. This chemical insight provides a broad foundation for all physical and biological sciences, opening up a variety of academic and professional pursuits.


Studying chemistry requires a multidisciplinary approach that incorporates other areas of study such as biology, computer science, mathematics, and physics. The diverse interests of chemists are reflected in the sub-disciplines of the field, such as analytical, biological, inorganic, organic, and physical chemistry.


Students at CSUB enjoy small class sizes, individual attention from their professors, high-tech laboratory equipment, and the opportunity to conduct hands-on research as undergraduates.


For additional information, visit the following:

Department of Chemistry & Biochemistry

Program Requirements - Chemistry, BS
